dc:description: RIPOR2 was first reported in relation to autosomal dominant nonsyndromic genetic deafness in 2020 (de Brujin et al; PMID: 32631815). Per criteria outlined by the ClinGen Lumping and Splitting Working Group, we found differences in inheritance pattern and phenotypic variability. Therefore, the following disease entities have been split into two disease entities, autosomal recessive nonsyndromic genetic deafness (OMIM:616515) and autosomal dominant nonsyndromic genetic deafness (OMIM:607017). The split curation for autosomal recessive nonsyndromic genetic deafness has been curated separately. One variant (in-frame deletion) that has been reported in over fifty probands from twelve families (with a founder effect demonstrated for at least seven of the families) in one publication (PMIDs: 32631815) is included in this curation. Analysis of this variant in mice shows mislocalization, supporting impaired function of protein. Thus, the mechanism of pathogenicity appears to be loss-of-function. This gene-disease relationship is also supported by experimental evidence (mouse model, expression-level evidence, PMID: 24958875). Heterozygous mutant mice show mild hearing loss. Expression-level evidence indicates that the gene is expressed in inner and outer hair cells. In summary, there is limited evidence to support this gene-disease relationship. Although more evidence is needed to support a causal role, no convincing evidence has emerged that contradicts the gene-disease relationship. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Hearing Loss GCEP on the meeting date 5/15/2024 (SOP Version 10).

evidence.dc:description: Only mild hearing loss was seen in the heterozygous mutant mice.
Both affected humans and mutant mice have mild hearing loss.
evidence.rdfs:label: Mouse model (heterozygotes have mild phenotype)

evidence.dc:description: FAM65B is shown in wild-type rat cochlea OHCs and in vestibular hair cells with moderate and high expression. Green fluorescent clusters indicating fusion-exocytosis vesicles in the pericuticular area. Localization of FAM65B to the supracuticular plasma membrane was observed.
evidence.rdfs:label: Rat inner and outer hair cell mice cell expression

evidence.dc:description: Upgrading an additional 0.5 pts. due to the founder effect.

The mutated region is part of a coiled-coil necessary for protein interactions. The mutant differs in localization from wild-type in mouse cochlear outer hair cells. Outer hair cells of wild-type mice were injectoporated at postnatal day 2 to express wild-type or mutated RIPOR2. Immunohistochemistry was used to analyze expression after two days. Mutated RIPOR2 did not rescue stereocilia issues in RIPOR2-depleted hair cells. Mutated RIPOR2 did not rescue stereocilia issues in RIPOR2-depleted hair cells.

evidence.rdfs:label: p.Gln566_Lys569del (20 genotype +, phenotype + members)
evidence.phenotypeFreeText: average age of onset was 30.6; milder phenotype, reduced penetrance in comparison to recessive cases
